content: Americans have always assumed that the key to undoing the all-encompassing framework of white supremacy lies, in part, in literacy. Literacy helped combat slavery in practical ways — reading and writing meant you could more easily escape by forging free papers, for example. But there was also literacy’s metaphysical promise — that you could write your way into new futures, into places that existed outside of imaginations made narrow by anti-blackness. Think of Frederick Douglass tricking white boys into teaching him to form letters, or Toni Morrison proudly displaying a letter from the Texas Board of Corrections declaring that it had banned her novel “Paradise,” because of its potential to start a riot. Books and reading are dangerous, which is why the question of which books are made available to children is always contested.

author: By John Wogan and Illustrations by Aurore de La Morinerie
title: Kenzo Takada’s Antique Artifacts
description: The designer, who founded the Kenzo label in 1970, relishes the storytelling powers of these ancient objects.
content: The Japanese designer Kenzo Takada first began collecting antiquities in the early 1990s while decorating his 14,000-square-foot townhouse in Paris’s Bastille neighborhood. The 81-year-old — who founded the fashion house Kenzo in 1970 and retired as its creative director in 1999 — is drawn to ancient statues, instruments, figurines and masks from Africa, Asia and Greece. “Once I started learning about these artifacts and the stories they told, I began to appreciate their history as much as their beauty as decorative objects,” he says. His collection has grown to include over 300 pieces, which he houses in a Haussmannian-style apartment beside the Seine, where he moved to in 2009. Takada sources many of his items from Japan and Hong Kong (he travels to Asia six times a year) and his favorite Paris antique shops. In January, the designer launched K三 (pronounced “K3”), a colorful home-décor line with Eastern influences that will introduce textiles, wallpaper, bedding, ceramics and rugs over the course of this year.

content: Sitting 500 feet above the sea, atop a cliff on Capraia, Italy — one of seven islands making up the Tuscan Archipelago — is a restored 16th-century fortress built to house Genoan soldiers. After hundreds of years of raids and takeovers by the French and British empires, Forte San Giorgio is a testament to a bygone era of both geopolitics and architecture: The property includes a 66-foot-tall watchtower and is surrounded on three sides by stone ramparts. title: South by Southwest Is Canceled as Coronavirus Fears Scuttle Festival
description: Hundreds of thousands of people were expected to arrive in Austin next week, but a number of companies had pulled out and on Friday, city officials called off the whole event.
content: The 34th annual edition of South by Southwest, the sprawling festival of music, technology and film in Austin, Texas, that has become a highlight on the global cultural calendar, was canceled by city officials on Friday over fears about the rapid spread of coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Top Coronavirus Official for U.S. Has Fought an Epidemic Before
description: Dr. Deborah Birx was appointed by President Barack Obama in 2014 to lead the government's fight against the global AIDS epidemic. Now she is coordinating the response to the coronavirus.
content: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 1983, even before the virus that causes AIDS had a name, a young Army doctor named Deborah L. Birx suffered excessive bleeding while giving birth. Moments before she passed out from pain, she screamed an order at her husband: “Do not let them give me blood!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Matt Stevens
title: Sanders Continues Attacks on Trade but Concedes Biden Could Beat Trump
description: “As we enter the moment in this campaign where we come down to a two-person race, I think it important for us to differentiate our records, and I intend to do that,” Mr. Sanders said.
content: DETROIT — Calibrating his approach for a tough head-to-head primary matchup in a year when many Democratic voters want to put up a united front, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on Friday renewed his attacks on former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s record on trade while also conceding that Mr. Biden could defeat President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Bill Clinton Explains Monica Lewinsky Affair as ‘Managing My Anxieties’
description: Mr. Clinton was asked about the scandal for the Hulu documentary series “Hillary.”
content: Former President Bill Clinton, recalling the sex scandal that led to his impeachment in 1998, says in a new documentary series that his extramarital affair with Monica S. Lewinsky was a way of “managing my anxieties.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro
title: The Hunt for Tape
description: How we tracked down a campus speech from 1988.
content: On Tuesday’s show, at minute 11:12, you hear a piece of archival tape. It’s the kind of historical audio we play all the time, in this case of former Vice President Joe Biden, delivering a speech in the late 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: South Bend Officer Will Not Be Charged in Shooting Death of Black Resident
description: The fatal shooting highlighted a strained relationship between former Mayor Pete Buttigieg and black residents in the Indiana town.
content: A police officer in South Bend, Ind., who fatally shot a resident last summer will not be charged, a prosecutor said Friday, capping a case that put a spotlight on the strained relations between Pete Buttigieg, then a presidential candidate and the mayor, and black residents in the town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: As Death Toll Mounts, Governments Point Fingers Over Coronavirus
description: The head of the World Health Organization said it was “not a time for excuses,” but some countries have been busily exchanging blame.
content: An Iranian official claimed without evidence that the epidemic could be an American bioweapon, after some U.S. officials said the same about China. Saudi Arabia said its cases were Iran’s fault. South Korea lashed out at Japan over travel restrictions and responded in kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: The Tax Code Is Overtaxed
description: The I.R.S. has become the de facto administrator of a startling number of social welfare programs.
content: When a working-class divorced couple takes turns caring for the kids, who deserves a hefty income subsidy to help offset the cost?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Handshake Is on Hold
description: And so is the hookup. Here’s how some people are dealing with social contact in the time of the coronavirus.
content: Myka Meier is an etiquette expert with more than 61,000 followers on Instagram. Strangers regularly approach her with questions about social and business protocol. But last Tuesday was something else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Halleck
title: Coronavirus Puts a Wrinkle in Wedding Industry
description: Some couples are cautiously moving ahead, while others are forced to delay their ‘I do’s’ for now.
content: JoAnn Gregoli, a 30-year veteran of wedding and event planning, has advice for couples with weddings on the horizon: don’t cancel because of the coronavirus, but instead, postpone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laraine Herring
title: What Used to Be, and What Is
description: My mother will tell you she doesn’t miss New York, but the past wraps the present with its ribbons.
content: My mother and I returned to her childhood apartment in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, in 2015. It had been 52 years since she moved away. She will tell you she doesn’t miss New York. She will tell you she has survived because she adapts, and that the past belongs in the past, no matter that I keep telling her the past wraps the present with its ribbons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Russo
title: New in Paperback: ‘Women’s Work’ and ‘What You Have Heard Is True’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: WOMEN’S WORK: A Personal Reckoning With Labor, Motherhood, and Privilege, by Megan K. Stack. (Anchor, 336 pp., $16.95.) Stack, a former international correspondent for The Los Angeles Times, explores her decision to employ Chinese and Indian women to care for her children, traveling to visit the women in their difficult home environments. “Stack is unflinching in her account,” our reviewer, Lauren Hilgers, wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grant Snider
title: It Takes Two to Tango
description: Grab a good book and get out on the dance floor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Coronavirus, Syria, Elizabeth Warren: Here’s what you need to know.
content: The number of new coronavirus cases rose sharply in the U.S. and Europe on Thursday, as stocks fell on both sides of the Atlantic and Britain and Switzerland reported their first fatalities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 1, Episode 7 Recap: Will Riker Makes Pizza
description: In this week’s episode, Picard reunites with his old Number One and his trusted counselor, Deanna Troi.
content: This week’s “Star Trek: Picard” is less about the central story arc and more about taking stock of who Picard is at this point in his life, as well as his android friend. The series creators have said that the show should be viewed more as a character study than anything else. And who better to assess the captain than his former “Number One,” William Riker? And his former ship’s counselor, Deanna Troi, the Betazoid who can sense emotions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Josef Newgarden, a Two-Time IndyCar Champion, Is Still Looking to Win Indy
description: Ahead of his ninth season, Newgarden dug in on downforce, Derek Jeter and going shirtless on “American Ninja Warrior.”
content: At 29, Josef Newgarden, already a two-time IndyCar champion, is readying for his ninth season in the sport. But Newgarden, a Nashville native, will tell you that winning the Indy 500, where his best finish so far is third, is what he most wants to achieve.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Late Night Says Elizabeth Warren ‘Realized She Was Overqualified’
description: Jimmy Fallon can’t blame the senator for not wanting to shake people’s hands right now. Stephen Colbert says her departure proves America can’t have nice things.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Brazen Shooting From a Window Terrifies Manhattan Neighborhood
description: Chaos erupted, and passers-by ran for cover, when the police warned about a gunman firing from above. One man was shot in the face.
content: Juan Manuel Gonzalez was looking for parking on a sunny, quiet street in Upper Manhattan when the sound of three gunshots startled him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: The Corner of N.Y.C. That’s Overrun by Deer, Turkeys and Feral Cats
description: Some Staten Island residents would like to hunt deer to reduce their numbers, but the city is pushing a vasectomy program.
content: You would think that Staten Island has plenty of room to share space with wildlife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josie Thaddeus-Johns
title: Armory Show to Trade Piers for the Javits Center
description: The next edition of the art fair will take place at the Javits in September, 2021.
content: After 19 years at the Piers, the Armory Show will move to the Javits Center in 2021. The high-profile art fair, which opened its 2020 edition earlier this week, has also been rescheduled for the fall, with the start of the galleries’ art season. The next show will take place Sept. 9 through Sept. 12, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: HuffPost’s Top Editor Leaves for a Podcasting Company
description: Lydia Polgreen, who has been the editor in chief at the news website since 2016, is stepping down for a role at Gimlet Media.
content: In another shake-up of the digital news landscape, HuffPost’s editor in chief, Lydia Polgreen, announced Friday that she was departing the website for a sector that many in media see as more of a growth area: podcasting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Vu
title: A Poem for International Women’s Day, Read by Vanessa Williams
description: As part of our series “Read T a Poem,” the actress performs a work by Maya Angelou.
content: Over her nearly 40-year career, Vanessa Williams has proved herself to be a master of reinvention. In 1983, she made history as the first African-American woman to be crowned Miss America, and later that decade she became a chart-topping musician with multiple platinum albums and a slew of Grammy nominations. From there, she moved on to theater, television and film acting — appearing most memorably as the witch in the 2002 Broadway revival of the musical “Into the Woods” and as the scheming magazine director Wilhelmina Slater in the TV series “Ugly Betty” — and in more recent years, she has co-written a memoir and introduced a fashion line. Now 56, the actress is embarking on yet another stage project: starring in a new production of the musical comedy “City of Angels,” which is currently in previews at the Garrick Theater in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: How I Came to Cook in French
description: For Melissa Clark, the food she grew up eating in Brooklyn, and the French cuisine her parents adored, laid the foundation for how she still cooks.
content: I can’t really speak French, but I cook in French. For years, I studied conjugations and the passé simple, practiced pronouncing yaourt and grenouille, but try as I might I just couldn’t seem to master it beyond the essentials like “deux pains au chocolat, s’il vous plaît.”

title: Alexei Botyan, Soviet Spy Hailed as ‘Hero,’ Dies at 103

content: As far as many Russians are concerned, Alexei Botyan, a Soviet spy during World War II, was a hero whose daring actions saved the Polish city of Krakow from destruction by the Nazis.

author: By John Branch and Chang W. Lee
title: Adam Ondra’s Race to the Top
description: Adam Ondra is the best climber in the world. But to win Olympic gold he needed to learn a new way to climb. Fast.
content: BRNO, Czech Republic — The world’s best climber is a wiry 27-year-old with a curly mop of hair and a noticeably long neck. His name is Adam Ondra, and on a misty fall day in an industrial valley on the outskirts of his hometown, he was inside the massive metal silo of a former rock quarry that had been converted into a climbing gym.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Henri Richard, Hall of Fame Center for Montreal Canadiens, Dies at 84
description: Richard played on 11 Stanley Cup-winning teams — five of them with his illustrious brother Maurice — and holds the record for game appearances with the Canadiens.
content: Henri Richard, the Montreal Canadiens’ Hall of Fame center who played on an N.H.L.-record 11 Stanley Cup winners and skated alongside his brother Maurice the Rocket when the Canadiens ruled hockey in the 1950s as the Flying Frenchmen, died on Friday in Laval, Quebec. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Michael Gold
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.: City Pleads for More Tests as Cases Rise
description: The city told the federal government that a shortage of tests for the virus had “impeded our ability to beat back this epidemic.”
content: New York City officials pleaded with the federal government on Friday to send more diagnostic kits for the new coronavirus, saying in a letter that the city’s limited capacity to test had “impeded our ability to beat back this epidemic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: This Black Hole Blew a Hole in the Cosmos
description: The galaxy cluster Ophiuchus was doing just fine until WISEA J171227.81-232210.7 — a black hole several billion times as massive as our sun — burped on it.
content: If there were ever sentient beings in the Ophiuchus cluster, a faraway conglomeration of galaxies in the southern sky, they are long gone. A few hundred million years ago, a mighty cosmic storm swept through that region of space. Hot gas suffuses the cluster, but the storm blew a crater through it more than a million light-years wide, leaving just a near-vacuum, a nattering haze of ultrahot electrical particles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie M. Hudson
title: What You Do to Your Women, You Do to Your Nation
description: Gender isn’t just a human interest sideshow to high politics.
content: In 1995, the U.N. World Conference for Women in Beijing championed the idea that the fate of nations was tied to the status of their female citizens. In 2000, U.N. Security Council Resolution 1325 asserted that peace is inextricably linked with gender equality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Florida Lobster Got a Break on China Tariffs. Then Came Coronavirus.
description: China, the biggest customer, took aim at the U.S. catch as the trade war escalated. Relief came this week, but now no one there is buying.
content: MARATHON, Fla. — Like other commercial fishermen along the east and west coasts, Ethan Wallace had been waiting 18 months for China — the world’s largest importer of live lobster — to lift its crushing retaliatory tariffs on American seafood that had whittled down his profits.

title: What Would a World Without Prisons Look Like?
description: The architect Deanna Van Buren designs civic spaces that are healing alternatives to correctional facilities.
content: Vicente Martinez, 18, was apprehensive the first time he visited the former drug house in Syracuse, N.Y. The building had been transformed into the Center for Court Innovation’s peacemaking program, where issues can bubble up and be resolved outside of the traditional criminal justice system. “I was messing up a lot,” Mr. Martinez recalled of his two previous stints in jail for driving a stolen vehicle across county lines. “I was doing dumb kid’s stuff.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin and Annie Flanagan
title: No Cell Signal, No Wi-Fi, No Problem. Growing Up Inside America’s ‘Quiet Zone’
description: Green Bank, W.Va., is home to a telescope so large that it requires near radio silence to operate, a technological restriction that has created a unique kind of modern childhood.
content: GREEN BANK, W.Va. — Viral dance memes and dance challenges on TikTok largely bypass Green Bank, W.Va. So do viral sensations like augmented reality filters on Snapchat and Instagram.

title: ‘Like Licking an Ashtray’: Fires’ Invisible Threat to Australia’s Wines
description: The smoke produced by the blazes that ravaged the country may ruin entire vintages, but detecting contamination is a guessing game.
content: HUNTER VALLEY, Australia — The hills are lush and green, the grapes plump and ripe. But one bite of this famed valley’s most prized product reveals a winemaker’s worst nightmare.

title: Paid to Stay Home: Europe’s Safety Net Could Ease Toll of Coronavirus
description: Europe’s social policies are sometimes seen as overly generous. Yet they may help cushion the economic impact of the virus.
content: PARIS — Keeping your salary while caring for a quarantined child. Exercising the right to not work if you are afraid of getting ill. Sick-leave pay for up to six months.
